subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Need common abbreviation list
msgSnippet: There are a couple of relevant files in our group s Resources directory: http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/Resources/ 1) Jon Zuck proposed the
messageBody:
There are a couple of relevant files in our group's Resources directory:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/Resources/

1) Jon Zuck proposed the revised letter names in "Second Shaw.htm". I
see three tiny mistakes in your chart: he has #12 as 'Zoos', #29 as
'Age', and #35 as 'Oil'.

2) The rationale for the keyboard layout (also by Jon Zuck) is in "QS
Keyboard Driver Remapping.htm".

I find the first document compelling. I haven't studied the second one
in detail. For some time I've wanted to come up with another keyboard
layout. I'd like to see all of the QS letters mapped to lower and
upper case Latin letters. Tossing out some of the mappings for
ligatures and half-letters, we could use 'W' for #20 and 'L' for #42,
for example. I'm undecided whether to suggest 'x' and 'X' for #43 and
#44, as a look at X-SAMPA suggests that 'x' would be good for #41. But
then I suppose a careful attempt to come up with single ASCII
characters to correspond to the 44 QS symbols based on X-SAMPA might
be difficult. I haven't tried yet.

Googling around a bit, I found a couple of other interesting ASCII
phonetic mappings, such as ENgliS:
http://foolswisdom.com/users/sbett/ENgliS.htm

And also Kirshenbaum notation: http://www.kirshenbaum.net/IPA/

Is there anyone else who'd like to see changes in the keyboard mappings?

Ted

> >
> > Where is there a list of this ascii mapping (font-mapping, I suppose)
> > to QS letter names/numbers?
> >
>
> I just created such a file:
>
>
> http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/schemes./names_num_letters.txt
>
> It is a plain text file. The first field is the revised name, followed
> by the letter, followed by the Unicode equivelent, followed by the
> hexidecimal number of the Unicode equivelent, followed by the number,
> followed by the old name.
>
> Paul
